title: A shopkeeper sold a watch at a 5% loss. If he purchases it at a 10% lower price and sells for rupees 140 more, his gain would have been one fourth of the cost price. What is the price of the watch? - Quora

response.answer_text: Statement of the given problem,A shopkeeper sold a watch at a 5% loss. If he purchases it at a 10% lower price and sells for rupees 140 more, his gain would have been one fourth of the cost price. What is the price of the watch?Let (C1, S1) & (C2, S2) denote respectively the original & the modified values of (cost-price, sell-price) of the given watch.Hence from above data we get following relations,S1 = (1 - 5/100)*C1or S1 = 0.95*C1 …. (1a)C2 = (1 - 10/100)*C1or C2 = 0.90*C1 …. (1b)S2 = S1 + 140 …. (1c)S2 - C2 = (1/4)*C1 …. (1d)Therefore from (1c) & (1d) we get,S1 + 140 - C2 = (1/4)*C1or 0.95*C1 + 140 - 0.90*C1 = (1/4)*C1 [from (1a) & (1b)]or (1/4 - 1/20)*C1 = 140or (1/5)*C1 = 140 or C1 = 700 (Rs) [Ans]

response.answer_text: Let CP of the watch =x. SP=0.95x If CP was 0.90x and SP 0.95x+₹140 gain would have been 0.90x/4 SP - CP = Gain => 0.95x +140 - 0.90x = 0.90x/4 => 0.95x + 140 - 0.90x = 0.225x => 0.175x = ₹140 therefore x= ₹ 800 Hence CP of the watch was ₹800 Let's check: CP =₹800 SP = ₹760 If CP was 720 and SP was 760+140 Profit would be 720/4 = ₹180 Verified
